title: Robert Kovač
text:
Robert Kovač (; born 6 April 1974) is a Croatian professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a> and former player who played as a <a href="centre-back">centre-back</a>. He was known for his ability with the ball and skill at dispossessing opponents. His older brother is football manager and former player <a href="Niko%20Kova%C4%8D">Niko</a>.
Club career.
Early career.
Kovač started his career in lower league clubs Rapide Wedding and <a href="Hertha%20Zehlendorf">Hertha Zehlendorf</a> before making his Bundesliga debut with <a href="1.%20FC%20N%C3%BCrnberg">1. FC Nürnberg</a> in 1995. Regularly featuring in the first–eleven, Kovač attracted much attention to himself and was signed at the end of the season by <a href="Bayer%2004%20Leverkusen">Leverkusen</a>.
Bayer Leverkusen.
He spent the next five seasons in Leverkusen without any significant success, as the club did not win any trophy during that period, although they were three times <a href="Bundesliga">Bundesliga</a> runners–up.
Bayern Munich.
After his contract expired he went to join reigning champions of <a href="2000%E2%80%9301%20Bundesliga">2000–01</a> season and <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> title holders, <a href="FC%20Bayern%20Munich">Bayern Munich</a>. In four seasons with Bayern he won two Bundesliga titles, two <a href="DFB-Pokal">German Cup</a> titles and the <a href="2001%20Intercontinental%20Cup">2001 Intercontinental Cup</a>.
Juventus.
On 15 July 2005, he signed for <a href="Juventus%20F.C.">Juventus</a>. He was one of the few first–team players that decided to stay in Juve following its demotion to <a href="Serie%20B">Serie B</a>. He made a total of 35 appearances and scored one goal before he moved back to Germany, this time for <a href="Borussia%20Dortmund">Borussia Dortmund</a>.
Borussia Dortmund.
On 1 August 2007, he signed for Borussia Dortmund, alongside another Croatian national team star, <a href="Mladen%20Petri%C4%87">Mladen Petrić</a>, who signed for the club two months earlier. Kovač had an unsuccessful comeback to the Bundesliga and was sold to <a href="Dinamo%20Zagreb">Dinamo Zagreb</a> at the winter transfer window of 2008–09 season.
Dinamo Zagreb.
On 29 January 2009, close to the January transfer window deadline, he signed 1 and a half year contract with <a href="Prva%20HNL">Croatian champions</a> Dinamo Zagreb. The club previously tried to sign him in the summer of 2007, but failed to meet his demands. Borussia Dortmund were compensated with €450,000. In his debut season Kovač made 12 appearances in the league and two more in <a href="Croatian%20Football%20Cup">Croatian Cup</a>. He started the <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20NK%20Dinamo%20Zagreb%20season">2009–10</a> season with a foot injury and missed all of Dinamo's matches in July and August, but returned to action at the start of the September. Kovač finished the season with a total of 22 appearances for Dinamo in all competitions, before it was officially announced on 1 June 2010 that he retired from active football.
International career.
Kovač represented <a href="Croatia%20national%20football%20team">Croatia</a> in two World Cups, <a href="2002%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2002</a> and <a href="2006%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2006</a>, and has also participated at two European Championships, <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202004">2004</a> and <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202008">2008</a>. At World Cup 2006 he played well in defence, however after picking up a second yellow against Japan he missed the final group match against Australia through suspension. Without Kovač, Croatia struggled in defence with his replacement Tomas committing handball for Australia's first goal via penalty kick. Croatia eventually drew 2–2 with Australia but were eliminated from the tournament. With Croatia, Leverkusen, and Bayern, Kovač was teammates with his older brother <a href="Niko%20Kova%C4%8D">Niko Kovač</a>. He retired from the national team in the fall of 2009, having captained the team after his brother's retirement in 2008.
Coaching career.
On 21 January 2013, <a href="Igor%20%C5%A0timac">Igor Štimac</a>, the head coach of the <a href="Croatia%20national%20football%20team">Croatia national football team</a>, announced that Kovač, alongside his older brother <a href="Niko%20Kova%C4%8D">Niko</a>, would take over as the <a href="Croatia%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Croatia national under-21 football team</a> head coach. From October 2013 until September 2015, he was also an assistant manager to his brother, then the head coach of the Croatia senior team.
On 1 July 2018, he became the assistant manager of <a href="FC%20Bayern%20Munich">Bayern Munich</a>. Robert's older brother, Niko, brought Robert with him to Bayern when he took over as the manager of the club. On 3 November 2019, he and his older brother parted ways with the club.
In July 2020, Kovač joined <a href="AS%20Monaco%20FC">AS Monaco</a> as assistant coach, with Niko serving as manager.
Personal life.
Kovač, along with his older brother <a href="Niko%20Kova%C4%8D">Niko</a>, was born in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a> to a family of Bosnian Croat <a href="immigrants">immigrants</a> from <a href="Livno">Livno</a>. He is married to a former Croatian model and <a href="Miss%20World%201995">Miss World 1995</a> first runner-up, <a href="Anica%20Kova%C4%8D">Anica Kovač</a>.
Honours.
